Brubeck, Connor
Highlight Festival
Sponsored By 'Y'
The massive hall- has been
leased, 5,000 chairs and a stage
set up, the piano hired, fire insurance procured, policemen and
Pinkerton guards contacted and
thousands of dollars worth of
tickets sold throughout the area
as the Hopkins YMCA prepares
to bring five of today's brightest
jazz stars to Baltimore for the
first Johns Hopkins University
Jazz Festival Monday night
starting at 8:30 p.m. at the Fifth
Regiment Armory.
"A wonderful educational opportunity as well as an evening
of good entertainment," according to Hopkins YMCA Executive
Secretary Dr. Chester H. Wickwire, the extremely varied concert will feature the talents of
Dave Brubeck and his quartet.
Maynard Ferguson and his orchestra, Chris Connor, the Lambert, Hendricks, Ross singers and
Chico Hamilton and his quintet.
Serious Jazz
"This concert will present
many aspects of the serious nature of jazz," said Dr.
Wickwire.
"The emphasis will be on listening, on jazz as a serious art
form.
Many of the artists appearing
are pioneers in the field who
feature many new, revolutionary
and experimental ideas."
Brubeck will highlight in his
performance famous saxaphonist
Paul Desmond, whose improvisations with the pianist have made
jazz history. They specialize
in
an intricate counterpoint
reminiscent, of Bartok, Stravinsky
and even Bach and have succeeded in combining these and
other classical-music influences
with current jazz modes.
New Conception
Singers Lambert, Hendricks
and Ross present something entirely new in conception. Like
Brubeck their contribution is a
unique combination of the new
and the old. The old in this case
is a series of famous songs of
Count Basie. The singers attempt
to recreate in vocal form the
effects and sounds these songs
first created as instrumentals.
Maynard Ferguson is a trumpet player who concentrates on
high-note style in his
renditions.
He will be backed up
Monday
night by his own large
-size
orchestra.
Chris Connor has a very low.

Vandalism
Student Council President
Bill DeVoe stated today he
intended to take strong measures to prevent the type of
vandalism
which
preceded
the Hopkins-Western Maryland football game last year
from occurring again.
While remaining mum on
the contents of the "strong
measures," DeVoe did point to
the fact that this year the
Student Council has both the
power and the machinery to
handle any trouble through
its judicial committee.
Last year several Hopkins
men went to Westminster
where they defaced Western
Maryland property, and engaged in such vandalism as
to cause Western Maryland
students to retaliate at Homewood. "This must not happen
again," warned DeVoe.

Pre-Law Society Initiated
For Outstanding Students
On Monday last there was
founded the Johns Hopkins PreLaw Society, an organization
established for outstanding undergraduates planning to go
into law as a career.
The speaker at this first meeting was A. Frederick Taylor, a
practicing attorney in Baltimore.
The topic of his talk was "General Practice of Law, as Opposed
to Specialist Practice.
Mr. Taylor, a graduate of
Washington College and the University of Maryland, is a member of the Bar Association of
Maryland. In his twenty years
of practice he had defended over
two thousand cases and has
taken seventy of them to the
Court of Appeals.

willingness to meet with them
singly or in groups. He hopes
this will give them "a more objective and better selection of
law as a career."

ROBERT HARVEY

Nineteen Hopkins Students
SeekFullbright Vacations
Nineteen Hopkins students,
both graduates and undergraduates, have applied for Fullbright
Scholarships, announced Dr. Sidney Painter, chairman of the
three-man Fullbright committee
here.
The committee, which includes Dean G. W. Shaffer and
Dr. D. C. Allen, in addition to
Dr. Painter, met Monday afternoon to review the applications.
But this committee, explained
Dr. Painter, could make only a
preliminary examination of the
applications, marking them into
categories such as "highly recommended," "less recommended," according to its own judgment.
Reviewed Later
The applications will be reviewed in detail in New York,
where they are to be sent by the
15th of this month.
The New York committee will
notify those applicants who it
rejects sometime in January,
said Dr. Painter. The remaining names, which will be divided
and marked according to first
choices and alternates, will then
be sent to the State Department
for approval.
From the State Department,
the applications will go to the
foreign countries involved. The
committees there will choose the
students they prefer from the
American list. In some cases an
alternate candidate may be selected in preference to the New
York committee's first choice.
However, noted Dr. Painter, this
does not occur often. Final results will be announced in April
or May.

Dormitory Council
Acts To Reinstate
Expelled Member
The Dormitory "Students Representative Council acted this
week to reinstate a house president who had been "temporarily
removed from office" by DSRC
President Stu Ran1ein last Friday following disturbances.
According to Hanlein, the
house president in question
created "quite a disturbance"
late Thursday night by cursing
and yelling. Feeling sudden action necessary, Hanlein immediately wrote a letter to the
offender "suspending him from
his office until we (the DSRC)
could have a hearing".
Monday's hearing produced a
decision by the Council to "reprimand the offender for his actions by means of a letter," said
Hanlein.
"We will also make it clear to
him that he was suspended for
his actions and will now be considered reinstated," he added.

Goucher Trustee
Mr. Hall is a member of the
Board of Trustees of Goucher
College and is vice-president of
the Baltimore YMCA.
Mr. Harvey, who attended Gilman and the Hill School, is a Phi
Beta Kappa graduate of Princeton University. He was named
president of the Maryland Trust
Company this year.
After graduation from Princeton in 1942 with an A. B. degree,
Mr. Harvey was commissioned in
the U. S. Army and served three
years with the rank of Captain
in the China Theater.
Rutgers Graduate Student
Mr. Harvey received a second
bachelor's degree from Johns
Hopkins in 1953 and then attended the Graduate School of
Banking at Rutgers University.
In 1948 he became assistant
secretary and assistant treasurer
of the Maryland Trust Company,
and then assistant vice-president
in 1950. On return from a threeyear leave of absence to serve
with the U.S. Government in
Washington, he was made vicepresident and subsequently executive vice-president.
A member of numerous professional and civic groups, Mr.
Harvey is a director or trustee of
several organizations including
YMCA, Children's Guild, Inc.,
Maryland Academy of Sciences,
Union Memorial Hospital, Maryland School for the Blind, Peabody Institute, Maryland Hospital Service, Baltimore Life Insurance Co.

United Nations
"The UN's Impact 'Round
the World" will be the topic of
a first-hand report by U.N.
fellowship members now visiting the United Nations in New
York. The talks will be given
Saturday, November 14, in
Levering Hall at 2:30 p.m.
Among those speaking will
be Leslie Ronald Aldous, Chief
Information Officer of the
United Nations Association;
Inder Jitt, correspondent of
"the Times of India"; Rastiaan Klaverstijn, Editor of
the Netherlands News Agency; Dr. Norberto de Ramos,
author, commentator, professor; and Luis Zalamea, from
the Office of Public Information of the United Nations.

As of November 13 the Alumni
Roll Call has netted $160,072.56
for the Johns Hopkins University.
Mr. Osmar P. Steinwald, director of Alumni Relations, announced to the News-Letter that
the total represents a participation of 18%, an average gift of
$25.31, and a total of 6324
donors. The 'money will be used
where it is needed on the JHU
campus.
The Alumni Roll Call, which is
the annual donation program for
the alumni, started on September 1 and will end on Dec. 31.

L. Dean Darbe graduated from Kansas State U. in 1955 with a
B. S. degree in electrical engineering. Today he is Supervising
Service Foreman for Southwestern Bell Telephone Company at
Hutchinson, Kansas. Dean has five Foremen and 58 craftsmen
reporting to him. He's got full responsibility—covering installation, maintenance, testing and repair—for 21,000 telephones and
all the equipment that serves them.
"It's interesting work," says Dean, "and it keeps me on the
go. Here are a few of my activities during a recent day on the job."

"8:30 a.m. I meet with one of our Foremen at the plant garage
to discuss a cable-pressurizing job. We're putting all aerial
cable in Hutchinson under air pressure to keep out moisture
which causes cable failure and costly service interruptions."

"10:15 a.m. My boss, District Plant Superintendent Randy
Barron, and I go over plans for an addition to our dial central
office. Several pieces of large and complex switching equipment
will have to be rearranged to tie in with the new facilities."

"1:30 p.m. After lunch, I drive out to the new plant of a mobile
home manufacturer. My men are completing installation of a
new-type cordless switchboard. I discuss features of the new
equipment with the firm's Vice President and Plant Manager."

"3:00 p.m. At our toll center we'll soon be adding another
test desk to increase our facilities for 'trouble shooting' Long
Distance circuits. Here, with our Chief Testboardman, I go
over some of the board changes which will have to be made."

CORRESPONDENCE

LOST

WEEKEND

Jazz for Baltimoreans

Next Monday night Johns Hopkins will present
something unique to the city in the form of the "Jazz for
Moderns" concert at the Fifth Regiment Armory. Never
in our memory have such high calibre modern jazz artists
been featured here in the same program. For those in
Baltimore as well as at IIopkins who appreciate the finest
in this type of music, Monday's concert will be an important and memorable event.
We wish to commend Dr. Chester Wickwire of the
Hopkins "Y" for persevering in this venture despite forbidding odds. His initiative has brought about not only
a worthwhile Hopkins enterprise but the possibility of
future such events, the calibre of which can only be
achieved when the city, too, supports them and shows its
appreciation as well.

By BILL ERTAG
Entering the final week of the
season the Jay bootmen, at 4-3-1,
will face two of their toughest
opponents of the year, Drexel
and Western Maryland.
Tomorrow, the Hopkins varsity
soccermen will travel to Philadelphia to pit forces against an
always strong Drexel soccer
team. The Engineers, who were
last year's national champions
with a 10-0 record, have a 3-4-1
mark so far this season. Hampered by injury the Engineers
started the year slowly, but have
bounced back quite strongly in
their last two contests to post
8-1 and 8-2 victories.
The Drexel pitchmen, who
have never been beaten by the
men from Homewood, boast a
strong offense which relies on
ball control, short passing and
brute scoring force. Under the
coaching of Dick Younger • the
bootmen from Pennsylvania
tripped the Jays 2-0 last year in
what proved to be a very exciting
and hard-played ballgame.
The men in Blue scored their

most of the way. In spite of
the inclement weather, Jim
Fitzpatrick and the two Swarthmore runners who preceded him
all broke the Hopkins course
record handily. Bruce Campbell, who finished fourth, barely
missed the mark. The new records will not be official, however, since the coures was slightly shortened to detour around
the football team's miry footpath
to the locker room.
Fence Climbing
Perhaps the most outstanding
feature of the race is that all

By HERB DORSEY
Assistant Sports Editor
After a busy week which saw
them lose two meets, the Hopkins cross country team journeys to Chester, Pa., tomorrow
for a triangular meet with Penn
Military Academy and Elizabethtown College.
About the only heartening
result from last week's action is
that Coach George Brown can
now be sure of his top five men.
Jim Fitzpatrick, Bruce Campbell, Steve Haust, Bob Hooper,
and Bob Ferree finished in that
order against both Swarthmore
and Loyola.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 13, 1959

DSRC Forbids Kidnaping, Engineering Mag
Urges Order In Drinking To Appear Soon
The DSRC at Monday's meeting, passed a resolution advising
discretion in the use of alcoholic
beverages by students in the
dorm and stating that all persons involved in unfortunate incidents while drinking will be
dealt with harshly.
A second resolution was also
passed by the DSRC condemning
kidnapping in the dorms by
either fraternity members or
pledges.
Both
of these resolutions
stemmed from Administration
views on the issues involved.
The problem of drinking arose at
a dinner attended by student
leaders and representatives of the
Administration on Wednesday,
November 4.
At the DSRC meeting President Hanlein stated that he

hoped the DSRC's action on the
matter would show the administration that the various student
regulatory bodies were able to
handle the problem, making
official intervention unnecessary.
Hanlein also expressed the opinion that if such action was not
taken, drastic steps might be
taken by the administration
ultimately leading to a complete
ban of alcohol.
The problem of kidnapping in
the dorms . was first brought up
by Dean W. K. Morrill.
Dean
Morrill, feeling that such actions
are potentinally dangerous, has
written letters to all national
fraternities represented on campus asking them for their position on such a policy. National frowning on such activities
will be asked to discipline chapters guilty of kidnapping.

With New Theme
The first issue of The Vector
will be issued on Friday. November 20. according to Lew Schuster, editor in chief.
The main theme of the engineering magazine is "What's
New At Hopkins" a major
article concerns the freshman
chemisty course which was instituted last year and received

much nation wide attention and
interest. The article was written
bY Maurice Bursey, a graduate
student and a freshman chemistry laboratory instructor.
Other articles in this issue of
The Vector include ,a story on a
generalized machine which can
make all types of electrical
equipment for lab work, the construction of a wind tunnel in
Maryland Hall. and an interview
with Mr. Rogers of the Place-

ment Bureau.
According to Schuster The
Vector is now formulating "long
range plans for the operation of
the magazine. Lots of information picked up by The Vector
staff is never passed on to new
members. Things like contacting
freshmen and maintaining the
staff need organizing each year.
We hope to put out a higher
class magazine for the University."

Brubeck, Connor
Highlight Festival
Sponsored By 'Y'
The massive hall- has been
leased, 5,000 chairs and a stage
set up, the piano hired, fire insurance procured, policemen and
Pinkerton guards contacted and
thousands of dollars worth of
tickets sold throughout the area
as the Hopkins YMCA prepares
to bring five of today's brightest
jazz stars to Baltimore for the
first Johns Hopkins University
Jazz Festival Monday night
starting at 8:30 p.m. at the Fifth
Regiment Armory.
"A wonderful educational opportunity as well as an evening
of good entertainment," according to Hopkins YMCA Executive
Secretary Dr. Chester H. Wickwire, the extremely varied concert will feature the talents of
Dave Brubeck and his quartet.
Maynard Ferguson and his orchestra, Chris Connor, the Lambert, Hendricks, Ross singers and
Chico Hamilton and his quintet.
Serious Jazz
"This concert will present
many aspects of the serious nature of jazz," said Dr.
Wickwire.
"The emphasis will be on listening, on jazz as a serious art
form.
Many of the artists appearing
are pioneers in the field who
feature many new, revolutionary
and experimental ideas."
Brubeck will highlight in his
performance famous saxaphonist
Paul Desmond, whose improvisations with the pianist have made
jazz history. They specialize
in
an intricate counterpoint
reminiscent, of Bartok, Stravinsky
and even Bach and have succeeded in combining these and
other classical-music influences
with current jazz modes.
New Conception
Singers Lambert, Hendricks
and Ross present something entirely new in conception. Like
Brubeck their contribution is a
unique combination of the new
and the old. The old in this case
is a series of famous songs of
Count Basie. The singers attempt
to recreate in vocal form the
effects and sounds these songs
first created as instrumentals.
Maynard Ferguson is a trumpet player who concentrates on
high-note style in his
renditions.
He will be backed up
Monday
night by his own large
-size
orchestra.

Vandalism
Student Council President
Bill DeVoe stated today he
intended to take strong measures to prevent the type of
vandalism
which
preceded
the Hopkins-Western Maryland football game last year
from occurring again.
While remaining mum on
the contents of the "strong
measures," DeVoe did point to
the fact that this year the
Student Council has both the
power and the machinery to
handle any trouble through
its judicial committee.
Last year several Hopkins
men went to Westminster
where they defaced Western
Maryland property, and engaged in such vandalism as
to cause Western Maryland
students to retaliate at Homewood. "This must not happen
again," warned DeVoe.

Pre-Law Society Initiated
For Outstanding Students
On Monday last there was
founded the Johns Hopkins PreLaw Society, an organization
established for outstanding undergraduates planning to go
into law as a career.
The speaker at this first meeting was A. Frederick Taylor, a
practicing attorney in Baltimore.
The topic of his talk was "General Practice of Law, as Opposed
to Specialist Practice.
Mr. Taylor, a graduate of
Washington College and the University of Maryland, is a member of the Bar Association of
Maryland. In his twenty years
of practice he had defended over
two thousand cases and has
taken seventy of them to the
Court of Appeals.

ROBERT HARVEY

Nineteen Hopkins Students
SeekFullbright Vacations
Nineteen Hopkins students,
both graduates and undergraduates, have applied for Fullbright
Scholarships, announced Dr. Sidney Painter, chairman of the
three-man Fullbright committee
here.
The committee, which includes Dean G. W. Shaffer and
Dr. D. C. Allen, in addition to
Dr. Painter, met Monday afternoon to review the applications.
But this committee, explained
Dr. Painter, could make only a
preliminary examination of the
applications, marking them into
categories such as "highly recommended," "less recommended," according to its own judgment.
Reviewed Later
The applications will be reviewed in detail in New York,
where they are to be sent by the
15th of this month.
The New York committee will
notify those applicants who it
rejects sometime in January,
said Dr. Painter. The remaining names, which will be divided
and marked according to first
choices and alternates, will then
be sent to the State Department
for approval.
From the State Department,
the applications will go to the
foreign countries involved. The
committees there will choose the
students they prefer from the
American list. In some cases an
alternate candidate may be selected in preference to the New
York committee's first choice.
However, noted Dr. Painter, this
does not occur often. Final results will be announced in April
or May.

Goucher Trustee
Mr. Hall is a member of the
Board of Trustees of Goucher
College and is vice-president of
the Baltimore YMCA.
Mr. Harvey, who attended Gilman and the Hill School, is a Phi
Beta Kappa graduate of Princeton University. He was named
president of the Maryland Trust
Company this year.
After graduation from Princeton in 1942 with an A. B. degree,
Mr. Harvey was commissioned in
the U. S. Army and served three
years with the rank of Captain
in the China Theater.
Rutgers Graduate Student
Mr. Harvey received a second
bachelor's degree from Johns
Hopkins in 1953 and then attended the Graduate School of
Banking at Rutgers University.
In 1948 he became assistant
secretary and assistant treasurer
of the Maryland Trust Company,
and then assistant vice-president
in 1950. On return from a threeyear leave of absence to serve
with the U.S. Government in
Washington, he was made vicepresident and subsequently executive vice-president.
A member of numerous professional and civic groups, Mr.
Harvey is a director or trustee of
several organizations including
YMCA, Children's Guild, Inc.,
Maryland Academy of Sciences,
Union Memorial Hospital, Maryland School for the Blind, Peabody Institute, Maryland Hospital Service, Baltimore Life Insurance Co.

United Nations
"The UN's Impact 'Round
the World" will be the topic of
a first-hand report by U.N.
fellowship members now visiting the United Nations in New
York. The talks will be given
Saturday, November 14, in
Levering Hall at 2:30 p.m.
Among those speaking will
be Leslie Ronald Aldous, Chief
Information Officer of the
United Nations Association;
Inder Jitt, correspondent of
"the Times of India"; Rastiaan Klaverstijn, Editor of
the Netherlands News Agency; Dr. Norberto de Ramos,
author, commentator, professor; and Luis Zalamea, from
the Office of Public Information of the United Nations.

L. Dean Darbe graduated from Kansas State U. in 1955 with a
B. S. degree in electrical engineering. Today he is Supervising
Service Foreman for Southwestern Bell Telephone Company at
Hutchinson, Kansas. Dean has five Foremen and 58 craftsmen
reporting to him. He's got full responsibility—covering installation, maintenance, testing and repair—for 21,000 telephones and
all the equipment that serves them.
"It's interesting work," says Dean, "and it keeps me on the
go. Here are a few of my activities during a recent day on the job."

"8:30 a.m. I meet with one of our Foremen at the plant garage
to discuss a cable-pressurizing job. We're putting all aerial
cable in Hutchinson under air pressure to keep out moisture
which causes cable failure and costly service interruptions."

"10:15 a.m. My boss, District Plant Superintendent Randy
Barron, and I go over plans for an addition to our dial central

"1:30 p.m. After lunch, I drive out to the new plant of a mobile

CORRESPONDENCE

LOST

WEEKEND

Jazz for Baltimoreans

Next Monday night Johns Hopkins will present
something unique to the city in the form of the "Jazz for
Moderns" concert at the Fifth Regiment Armory. Never
in our memory have such high calibre modern jazz artists
been featured here in the same program. For those in
Baltimore as well as at IIopkins who appreciate the finest
in this type of music, Monday's concert will be an important and memorable event.
We wish to commend Dr. Chester Wickwire of the
Hopkins "Y" for persevering in this venture despite forbidding odds. His initiative has brought about not only
a worthwhile Hopkins enterprise but the possibility of
future such events, the calibre of which can only be
achieved when the city, too, supports them and shows its
appreciation as well.

By HERB DORSEY
Assistant Sports Editor
After a busy week which saw
them lose two meets, the Hopkins cross country team journeys to Chester, Pa., tomorrow
for a triangular meet with Penn
Military Academy and Elizabethtown College.
About the only heartening
result from last week's action is
that Coach George Brown can
now be sure of his top five men.
Jim Fitzpatrick, Bruce Campbell, Steve Haust, Bob Hooper,
and Bob Ferree finished in that
order against both Swarthmore
and Loyola.
Last Saturday's Middle Atlantic meet with Swarthmore was
perhaps the most unusual that
has been seen around the
Homewood in quite a while. Running in a steady downpour, the
harriers had slippery footing for

contests of the year, holding
Swarthmore to eight first downs.

passing. About half of this total
came on a 50-yard Quaker drive
in the second quarter, the visitors' only real move of the game.

NEWS -LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. 13, 1959

DSRC Forbids Kidnaping, Engineering Mag
Urges Order In Drinking To Appear Soon
The DSRC at Monday's meeting, passed a resolution advising
discretion in the use of alcoholic
beverages by students in the
dorm and stating that all persons involved in unfortunate incidents while drinking will be
dealt with harshly.
A second resolution was also
passed by the DSRC condemning
kidnapping in the dorms by
either fraternity members or
pledges.
Both
of these resolutions
stemmed from Administration
views on the issues involved.
The problem of drinking arose at
a dinner attended by student
leaders and representatives of the
Administration on Wednesday,
November 4.
At the DSRC meeting President Hanlein stated that he

hoped the DSRC's action on the
matter would show the administration that the various student
regulatory bodies were able to
handle the problem, making
official intervention unnecessary.
Hanlein also expressed the opinion that if such action was not
taken, drastic steps might be
taken by the administration
ultimately leading to a complete
ban of alcohol.
The problem of kidnapping in
the dorms . was first brought up
by Dean W. K. Morrill.
Dean
Morrill, feeling that such actions
are potentinally dangerous, has
written letters to all national
fraternities represented on campus asking them for their position on such a policy. National frowning on such activities
will be asked to discipline chapters guilty of kidnapping.

With New Theme
The first issue of The Vector
will be issued on Friday. November 20. according to Lew Schuster, editor in chief.
The main theme of the engineering magazine is "What's
New At Hopkins" a major
article concerns the freshman
chemisty course which was instituted last year and received

much nation wide attention and
interest. The article was written
bY Maurice Bursey, a graduate
student and a freshman chemistry laboratory instructor.
Other articles in this issue of
The Vector include ,a story on a
generalized machine which can
make all types of electrical
equipment for lab work, the construction of a wind tunnel in
Maryland Hall. and an interview
with Mr. Rogers of the Place-

ment Bureau.
According to Schuster The
Vector is now formulating "long
range plans for the operation of
the magazine. Lots of information picked up by The Vector
staff is never passed on to new
members. Things like contacting
freshmen and maintaining the
staff need organizing each year.
We hope to put out a higher
class magazine for the University."
